message: never even heard of it
Yes, it's awesome
yah, it's pretty useful for HTML parsing, better alternative to BeautifulSoup.
but now that I'm looking at the docs it looks awesome
only downside of it that I'm seeing so far: it reduces the incentives to not use XML
anybody using this? is it ready to use?
Built on lxml so it's fast
I've only used the parsing part of it

The main thing I want to add: a namespace-naive version which I could use with XML to simply say things like "foo bar[href]" rather than needing ubiquitous hard-core wankery to add the full {path/to/xlink/wtf} namespace to every XPath expression
I use it all the time of random screen scrapping hacks.  It even works with XML.  I used it to fetch an Atom feed and only emit the entries that I want to see based on a list of patterns.
Looks very nice - I've been doing the odd scraping job of late with BeutifulSoup, but there's plenty more out there worth looking at, it seems. lxml.html, the Djangoey Sracpy, this..
I am with @ericmortiz, great for quick and dirty screen scraping. however, that's the extent of my use so far.
I always assumed html5parser was for, well, html5
Haha, wow. I'll def have to give it a try

@kennethreitz I can't promise miracles but science.nasa.gov until last spring was a collection of HTML from two prior CMSes, many different tools (Dreamweaver, Word, etc.) and about 15 years of hand-editing dating back to 1995.
wow, great module. thx for the tip :)

twas a nightmare.

@kennethreitz Have you tried lxml's html5parser? html5lib has killed my need for BeautifulSoup and the last heavy project I used it on was a pretty exhaustive stress-test for malformed HTML
both are static html
pyquery is great for testing
lxml.html is best, but sometimes html is just too darn broken and you have to use BeauifulSoup
lxml should sphinx it up
I love when that happens
every update done by hand

@kennethreitz It is, but you have to remember that the major advance in html5 was both rejecting XML-style strict parsing and codifying the error handling rules, and they were smart enough to base those rules on existing browsers to handle developers who considered loading in IE validation. What that meant in practice was that it failed in ways similar to existing browsers - and the handful of severely broken pages where I tested that did indeed not even render in any browser I tried
I installed it. Works as advertised, just saddened to see that the method names don't follow PEP 8.
@jesse_dhillon time to make a pep8 fork :)
@jesse_dhillon but I think it's trying to follow jquery syntax
And a foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds ;-)
@davedash @holdenweb Monkey patching it to have conforming names would be trivial

lxml supports xpath and css selector syntax, why is pyquery a good idea?
you can open firebug, jquerify the webpage and type $('...') commands within the command line
